The Opera of O B E R O N
was last Tuesday, honoured by an immense overflow from every part of the Theatre the moment the
Doors were opened—it will be repented This Evening & Tuesday next, which will be the only night.
it can he acted on account of the production of ROSSINI'* N E W OPERA.
_
In consequence of the great success which has attended the revival of FA&QUHAR'S Comedies of The

RECRUITING OFFICER, und the BEAUX STRATAGEM,
Those Comedies will be acWd in alternate weeks quriay LatJt.

The MAID OF 3UDAH; or, KNIGHTS TEMPLARS.
Produced on Saturday, (the Music entirely by ItOSSINTJ
was received, not
only without a dissenting voire, but with unqualified and genuine approbation
from the beginning to the end—the Theatre was full in every part, and at the
fall of the Curtain the most rapturous and unanimous applause crowned the
Performance. I n consequence of the nature of
Miss PATON's
engagement, it can only be presented twice a week during Lent, which will
he on Tuesdays and Saturdays.

The MAID OF JUDAH; or, KNIGHTS TEMPLARS,
(the Music entirely by ROSSINI)
was received on its 2d representation, by a
numerous and brilliant audience with the same marks of enthusiastic approbation that distinguished its first performance. But in consequence of the nature of
Miss PATON s
engagement, it can only be presented twice a week during Lent, which will
be on Tuesdays and Saturdays.

*

The MAID OF JUDAH; or, KNIGHTS TEMPLARS,
(the Music entirely by ROSSIS/1J wax received on its 2<l representation, by a

T H I S EVENING, FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 1820,
U n d e r t h e sole m a n a g e m e n t a n d direction of Mr. H A W E S ,
WILL BC P E S - O R M E D A

Grand Selection of Antlent and Modern Music.
PART I.

A SELECTION FROM HANDEL'S ORATORIO

JUDAS MACCAREUS.
Overture.
Recitative. Mr. .t. O. A T K I N S , " Haste w e . "
Chorui, " Mourn ye afflicted children."
Chorus, " Hear ui, O Lnrd."
Recitative, MistEARRAK, " Daughters l a ymn 'distressful."
,
Chorus, " Fall'n is the foe."
Duet, Mrs. K N Y V E T T and Mist FARRAR, " From this dread."
Heeitative, Mr. W. K V Y V E T T , " Oh, let eternal honour*."
Recitative, Mr. J . 0 . A T K I N S , " Not vain la nil."
Air, " From mighty kin*:Air, Mrs. KNYVF.TT, *' Pious orgies, pious airs."
Recitative, Mr. P H I L L I P S , " Be comforted."

was produced last night—its reception was most satisfactory—great applause followed e v e r ,
Scehe—and the conclusion was crowned l>y rapturous approbation, without a dissentient voice.

The successful Opera of

T h e MAID O F J U D A H ; or, K N I G H T S TEMPLARS,
continues to be performed with unabated attraction—The Boxes are greatly taken for many nights t»
come—But in consequence of the nature of
Miss
P A T O N's
engagement, it can only be acted three times more before Easter, viz.—-on Saturday and Monday
next—and Saturday, April i l t h ; after which that Lady will be absent till a fortnight after Easter.

Home, sweet Home! or theRanz desVachei
has proved the most popular two-act Opera of the season—it was performed last night for the 4th
time, to an audience filling every part of the Theatre—It can only bo acted (before Easter) on
Thursday next—1 hursday, April », and Saturday the 11th,—after which
Madame V E S T R I S
takes a Conge for a fortnight.

In consequence of the undiminished attraction ofShakspeare's

Tragedy of

ROMEO AND JULIET,

The P a r t of JULIET by Miss F A N N Y KEMBLE.
A N E W S T A I R C A S E leading to the Dress Circle only, has been constructed at t h . Bow-street
Entrance, whteh will be exclusively appropriated to the accommodation of those parties who may
purchase Ticket* at the Box-office at the time of taking Places.
PLACES for the BOXES to be had at the Box-Office, Hart-street, from Ten till Four; when PrWaL B.iea
can also be bad.

Curtain are put under the direction of the new Metropolitan Police.

COPY of a COMMUNICATION from Mr. C.KEiMRLE
RJ
to the PUBLIC JOURNALS.
Copies of three Letters written to Mr. KEAN by Mr. BART LEY, Stage
of (Jovcnt Garden Theatre.

(Being her 25rA appearance on any Haft.)

LadyOapwlet, Miss LACY,

Nurse, Mrs. DAVENPORT,

i n act I. a Masquerade

and Dance

Theatre Royml Covent Garden, November21,

In actY. The Funeral Procession of Juliet, and a Solemn Dirge.

I wus waiting with Mr. Kcmble in expectation of the pleasure of meeting you here as
appointed at our interview yesterday, when your letter of this morning was delivered to me. Mr.
Kemble requests me to say that h e ' i s most anxious to consult your convenience, but the nights of
Monday, AVcdnesday and Friduy in next week, which you suggest for your performances, are
advertised, for ROMEO und JULIET, und I need not xny to you thai our duty to the Public* renders any
alteration mm impossible. As you observe that you can piny on no other nights but those you have
been accustomed to in both the London Theatres, I can only assure you that every endeavour shall
be made to comply with your wishes. Before, however, vvu wtv more on this point, Mr. Kemble
dewires that I should remind you, in allusion to the intimation Which you made to me yesterday of
vour intention to enter into an engagement in London for thiseeflaofl, tlmt (here is an engagement
subsiKtinii betWflOO. you untl Covent Garden whicli preclude, your miing in London during the
present season, und he thinks it just to all parties tlint ihis shoald not eWaVM nltetition. It will
afford Mr. Keiuble much salibfaction to accommodate eneunistunocs to your present views, and
difficult as it will be at this advanced period of the Season to make such alteraiioas in the arrangements of the Theatre, (which arrangements have t.ecn made on the faith of your agreement) as will
finable him to do so, he is ready to encounter such difficulty on your account, and with this feeling he
•was prepared to make you an offer of an engagement for tins season, had you been able to meet him.
As you are unwell to day, if you will fa\ or us with an appointment for tomorrow, Mr. Kemble will
be happy to talk the matter over Willi you.
You will be kind enough to receive this communication expressly on the understanding that it is
made without prejudice to your present agreement with Covent Garden Theatre.

The O V E R T t n i E awl the whole of the M U S I C selected from D I B D I N S S O N G S .

V I E W O F T H E DOWNS.

Theatre Royal Cotent Garden, Thursday,

I hoped you would before this have favoured Mr. Kemble with an appointment, as I
requested in my letter of Tuesday the 2 1th. I think he would have proposed an arrangement, that
wculd have been found satisfactory.—Pray let DM have the pleasure of hearing from you.
I am, &c.
GEORGE BARTLEY.
To Edmund Kean, Esq.

On
On
(>»
On

Sunday Morning, No*. 29, 182f.

I have just learned that you were last night served with the Injunction, restraining you from
the intended violation of your engagement with Covent Garden Theatre—I have not seen Mr. C .
Kemble since, but I am so fully in possession of his sentiments, that, though the duties of his situation
tendered it imperative on him, in consequence of your total disregard of the two letters I addressed
fo you on the 24th and 26th instant, to appeal to the law, I am satisfied h e is still ready, as
expressed in my letter to you of the 24th, (and to which I earnestly solicit your attention) to e n counter, on your account, the difficulty I therein pointed out to you, in order to meet your wishes for
the present season ; and I am very confident, the same arrangement may take place if you choose
to avail yourself of it, as would have been made known to you, had you thought proper to taks
any notice of either of those letters.
I shall take an early opportunity this day of seeing Mr. Kemble, and unless you hear from me in
the course of the morning to the contrary, you may consider that he does not withdraw from the
proposal which it was his intention to have made to you.
B u t ! think it fair to apprise you, that knowing Mr. Kemble's sense of obligation to the Public,
I am induced to think he will concur with me, in the necessity of publishing my communications to
you, at the earliest possible period.
I am, &c.
(Signed)
GEORGE BARTLEY.

will be acted next week.

Mr. ELIASON
Hie first tppeerance) will perform on the Violin an Air Danois, with Variations by Maymler.

Tlie Comhn tor of the Oratorios ventures to flatter himself, that, although his announcement
does not embrace the names of some of the long-acknowledged " STARS," he has succeeded
in securing the assistance of so great a body of Talent as will afford the highest satisfaction to
all Lovers of Music : his aim is to bring forward the rising Talent of the Country, and he trusts
and believes that the effort will be appreciated by the Public.

Leader for this Evening, Mr. LODEK.

T H E A T R E ROYAL,

COVKNT G A R DEN;
April 23, 1830.

MR. F A W C E T T having signified his intention of quitting the Stage at t h .
Close of the present Season, tlie following Professional Gentlemen held a MEETING this day,
in th« T h e a t r e Mr. C. KEMBLE,

Mr. B L A N C H A R D ,

Mr. M E A D O W S ,

SIR G E O R G E S M A R T ,

Mr. D U R U S E T ,

Mr. P O W E R ,

Mr. M A T H E W S ,

Mr. E G E R T O N ,

Mr. W A R D E ,

Mr BARTLEY,

Mr. F A R L E Y ,

Mr. W R E N C H .

Mr. ABBOTT,

Mr. K E E L E Y ,

Mr. C. K E M B L E was unanimously

called to the Chair.

Resolved,—THAT
the Gentlemen present do form themselves into a Committee for
the purpose of assisting Mr. FAWCETT, by every means in their power, on his B E N E F I T ,
Thursday, May 20, being the Last Night of his Appearance—that his retirement may be as
brilliant as his professional talent and private worth have been conspicuous.
Resolved,—THAT such Members of the Committee who are Subscribers to the Covtnt
Garden Theatrical Fund, do acknowledge with gratitude and pride, that chiefly to Mr.
FAWCETT'S exertions for more than 20 years, they owe the present prosperity of their Institution, whereby many Widows and veteran Actors are supported and relieved.
Resolved,--THAT
as Miss F A N N Y KEMBLE, and Mr. M A T H E W S , Mr. Y O U N G ,
Mr. L I S T O N , and Mr. J O N E S , have already kindly volunteered their servicesn, That application be made to other distinguished Members of the Profession, to assist in varying the
Entertainments, and enable the Committee to carry into effect the desirable object which they
have in view.
(Signed)

C H A R L E S KEMBLE,

Mr. F A W C E T T will act the Character of CAPTAIN C O P P ,
For his Last
Performance.

Prtntwl by W R»yroldiv V. Denmark-Court Strtad,

Chairman.

Warden.
